awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Infusion of Evidence-Based Strategies to Enhance STEM Majors' Mathematics Performance
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate program provides support to design, implement, study and assess efforts to increase the numbers of students and the quality of their preparation by strengthening science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and research. This project at the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff provides a strategic approach to reform the introductory mathematics curriculum to increase student success. Undergraduate students are involved in this project as peer leaders and researchers.

The project seeks to develop faculty expertise in evidence-based instruction, specifically research and project-based learning, web-based learning, and peer-led team learning, and to infuse these strategies into introductory mathematics courses. It is envisioned that these  approaches will improve the retention and graduation rates of STEM majors at the university. The proposed activities are: to update the College Algebra curriculum incorporating evidence-based instructions methods and pilot two courses; to develop a co-requisite College Algebra curriculum and pilot a course; and to develop a peer-led team learning center. The project is guided by formative and summative evaluation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff (UAPB) has been one of the most effective public Historical Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) in Arkansas to serve both African-American and first-generation college students. UAPB produced a good number of students majoring in Science, Technology, Engineering, or Mathematics (STEM).  However, the College Algebra course has been one of the main problems for many STEM majors to change to non-STEM majors.  This project addressed this major problem by implementing evidence-based (EB) instructions utilizing iPad and peer-led-team-learning (PLTL) study sessions. 

UAPB math faculty members understand the advantages of evidence-based active learning and teaching but are hesitant to embrace such teaching methods due to the lack of supporting materials and proper training. Through this project, most of the  UAPB math faculty are equipped to implement evidence-based instructions.  The PI and math faculty developed new course materials and updated current course materials to enhance teaching and learning Mathematics.  During the summer faculty development workshop, the PI and her colleagues created WebAssign and XYZ Textbook assignments and exams for Elementary, Intermediate, and College Algebra courses.  The PI developed and implemented a Co-Requisite College Algebra course, which helped STEM students to save their time and cost to graduate.   The PI also trained other faculty to teach the Co-Requisite College Algebra course.  Co-Requisite College Algebra students' evaluations showed positive feedback, and the Co-Requisite College Algebra course passing rates are also as good as regular College Algebra courses. 

Many UAPB students do not have adequate technology (computer or tablet) to do their assignments and projects.  Through this project, the PI purchased 45 iPads and Apple Pencils; students can use this equipment in class, PLTL lab, and check out the equipment for a semester.  Students did their WebAssign assignments on the iPad, took notes, and programmed in Julia via JuliaBox.

The PI and her collaborator, a senior computer programmer at the National Center for Toxicology Research (NCTR), created class and semester coding projects in the Julia computer language.  Participated students learned the basics of Julia programming and created their own Julia functions to solve abstract math problems into meaningful problems.  According to students' survey results, knowing some programming skills helped students to understand math problems and also boosted their confidence.  The PI trained PLTL leaders on how to be effective PLTL leaders, and they had a weekly meeting to address any issues and concerns.  Math faculty usually choose PLTL leaders who know students' math content abilities and temperament from previous academic years.

This project has essentially affected all STEM majors at UAPB, particularly underrepresented minority and women undergraduate students. There is an increase in the STEM retention rate by improving mathematics performance, which is equivalent to more qualified STEM graduates. This project thus addressed the nation's dire shortage of qualified STEM workforce, especially minority STEM workforce. The project has some related positive broader impacts: 1) Purchased project equipment and supplies will be continuously utilized in other math classes to implement EB instructional practices, which will enhance more students' mathematics performance and coding experiences; 2) Uploaded EB instructional materials and activities can be utilized by other UAPB STEM departments and other HBCU institutions to produce more STEM graduates; 3) Created Julia projects can be used as a demo for outreach programs in local schools and community; and 4) Student participants enhanced their mathematics content knowledge, equipped with technology, and obtained computer programming skills.


Last Modified: 09/15/2021
Modified by: Anna Harris
